result.markdown: --- title: "Penguin" format: html: code-link: true code-fold: true code-summary: "Show the code" self-contained: true embed-resources: true toc: true theme: Zephyr number-sections: false execute: warning: false message: false echo: false editor_options: chunk_output_type: console fig-cap-location: margin --- ## Introduction This document offers a straightforward analysis of the well-known penguin dataset. It is designed to complement the [Productive R Workflow](https://www.productive-r-workflow.com) online course. You can read more about the penguin dataset [here](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/). Let's load libraries before we start! ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(hrbrthemes) # ipsum theme for ggplot2 charts library(patchwork) # combine charts together ``` ::: ## Loading data The dataset has already been loaded and cleaned in the previous step of this pipeline. Let's load the clean version, together with a few functions available in `functions.R`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Source functions source(file = "functions.R") # Read the clean dataset data <- readRDS(file = "../data/data_clean.rds") ``` ::: ![](images/culmen_depth.png){fig-align="center" width="300"} ## Bill Length and Bill Depth Now, let's make some descriptive analysis, including summary statistics and graphs. What's striking is the slightly negative relationship between `bill length` and `bill depth`: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} data |> ggplot( aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm) ) + geom_point(color = "#69b3a2") + labs( x = "Bill Length (mm)", y = "Bill Depth (mm)", title = paste("Surprising relationship?") ) + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Relationship between bill length and bill depth. All data points included.](analysis_author_module_2_files/figure-html/surprising_relationship_plot-1.png){fig-align='center' width=480} ::: ::: It is also interesting to note that `bill length` a and `bill depth` are quite different from one specie to another. This is summarized in the 2 tables below: ::: {.cell layout-ncol="2"} ```{.r .cell-code} data %>% group_by(species) %>% summarise(average_bill_length = mean(bill_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 2 species average_bill_length 1 Adelie 38.8 2 Chinstrap 48.8 3 Gentoo 47.5 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} data %>% group_by(species) %>% summarise(average_bill_depth = mean(bill_depth_mm, na.rm = TRUE)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 2 species average_bill_depth 1 Adelie 18.3 2 Chinstrap 18.4 3 Gentoo 15.0 ``` ::: ::: Now, let's check the relationship between bill depth and bill length for the specie `Adelie` on the island `Torgersen`: ::: {.cell layout-ncol="3"} ```{.r .cell-code} # # Use the function in functions.R p1 <- create_scatterplot(data, "Adelie", "Togersen") p2 <- create_scatterplot(data, "Chinstrap", "Biscoe") p3 <- create_scatterplot(data, "Gentoo", "Dream") p1 ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](analysis_author_module_2_files/figure-html/relationship-1.png){width=288} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} p2 ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](analysis_author_module_2_files/figure-html/relationship-2.png){width=288} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} p3 ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](analysis_author_module_2_files/figure-html/relationship-3.png){width=288} ::: :::
